items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  9.08
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Hardy Childers, Interim Associate Superintendent of Business Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2010/2011-43 Intent to Lease District Property for Cellular and Wireless Communication Antenna Purposes
		 
The District has received additional interest from cellular and wireless communication providers to lease property at the district’s school sites and other facilities for the purpose of installing and maintaining cellular and wireless communication antennas.  The Board has previously awarded such lease agreements to carriers Verizon, T-Mobile and Clear Wire.  Antennas potentially would be installed on light poles around the football stadiums at each of those campuses, on rooftops, or as otherwise approved by the District.  Other school districts have entered into such agreements as a means of generating lease income including, most recently, San Jose Unified School District.  
		 
Administration seeks the Board’s approval to accept additional lease proposals at all of the District’s sites.
		 
At the September 17, 2009, Regular Board Meeting, the Board held a public hearing to solicit community input on the potential leasing of District property for such purposes.  Before Administration can fully negotiate any such lease with any proposed lessee the Board must by 2/3rds vote (4 out of 5 Members) approve a Resolution of Intent to lease property and then advertise the notice of the approved resolution locally, including that the District will be accepting offers to lease such property upon minimum rental terms.  Each lease could generate approximately $30,000 annually, or more.
		 
Any offers to lease would be opened and examined at a subsequent regular Board meeting, and any lease agreements would be subject to final Board approval.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Lease revenue to be determined
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2010/2011-43 by a 2/3rds majority declaring the District’s intent to lease District property as described in the Resolution.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  10.01
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discuss and/or Approve Program Improvement Year 4 School Alternative Governance Plans
		 
Local Educational Agencies (LEA) who have schools in Program Improvement, Year 4 are responsible for working with the schools to develop a restructuring/alternative governance plan.  Andrew Hill and Independence High Schools are both in Year 4 and have been working with the District to analyze progress and construct a plan.
		 
Schools in Program Improvement Year 4 are required to do the following:
Create a District and School Liaison Team (DSLT).  This team leads the school through the PI Year 4 planning process and chooses a restructuring/alternative governance plan.  A DSLT was created at both sites following the State suggested composition, that is, supervisor of the principal, curriculum and instruction administrator, classroom teachers, member of the school’s advisory council, parents, and other informed individuals.  Each DSLT met twice and followed the CDE recommended protocol to select appropriate alternative governance option(s) and revise the Single Plan for Student Achievement.
Allow adequate opportunity for teachers and parents to comment before taking action. With assistance from committee members, information was shared and stakeholders had opportunities to comment on suggested plans.  Andrew Hill held town hall meetings with staff and parents to gather input, and Independence shared their progress with staff at meetings and parents during School Site Council meetings.
Choose one of the four following options as their restructuring/alternative governance structure.
               a.  Close the school and reopen it as a charter school.
               b.  Replace all or most of the school staff (which may include the principal) who are
                    relevant to the failure to make AYP.
               c.  Enter into a contract with an entity, such as a private management company with
                    a demonstrated record of effectiveness, to operate the public school.
               d.  Implement any other major restructuring of the school's governance arrangement
                    that makes fundamental reforms and leads to improved student achievement.
		 
          After completing the CDE recommended protocol, Andrew Hill and Independence selected 
          D, that is, to implement an alternative governance structure.
		 
          Andrew Hill High School plan for alternative governance structure - The main focus areas   
          of alternative governance structure are as follows:
  
                 *  Smaller Learning Communities
                 *  Whole school participation by department of Professional Development focusing
                     on engaging students
                 *  Assessing student learning
                 *  Extending learning to close the achievement gap
		 
		 
           Independence High School plan for alternative governance structure - The three main
           focus areas of their alternative governance structure are as follows:
		 
                 *  Develop and align instruction with content standards with focus on English language
                     learners and special education.
                 *  Implement common assessments and ongoing collaboration to inform staff about the
                     effectiveness of instruction.
                 *  Implement an intervention plan for students with multiple "F" grades.
          
      4. Ensure that the school’s Single Plan for Student Achievement reflects the alternative
          governance structure chosen above.
		   
          The alternative governance structure is represented in both Andrew Hill's Single Plan for
          Student Achievement and Independence's Single Plan for Student Achievement.
		 
          The DSLT will continue to meet on a regular basis at both high schools to look at student 
          achievement data and monitor the alternative governance plan.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Governance Structures at Andrew Hill and Independence High Schools.

SUBJECT:
Approve the Appointment of Representatives to the South East Special Education Local Planning Areas Community Advisory Council Meetings
		 
		 
The South East Special Education Local Planning Areas (SELPA) Community Advisory Council (CAC) is made up of parent representatives from the eleven districts that make up the South East SELPA.  Each member district is charged with the responsibility of having a parent that serves as a liaison to share and bring information for parents of students with special needs.  Dianne Lemke and Janice Richason, parents of special needs students, were recommended by the ESUHSD Special Services Advisory Group to serve on South East SELPA CAC for a term of two years.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the appointment of Dianne Lemke and Janice Richason to represent East Side Union High School District at the South East SELPA CAC Meetings.

Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Cari Vaeth, Director of Adult Education and Career Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Approve Carl D. Perkins 132 Grant 2011-12 Grant Application for East Side Union High School District
		 
		 
Overview:
The East Side Career Technical Education Program includes the AH Multimedia Academy, AH Culinary Arts Pathway, AH Biotechnology Academy, AH Heath/Nursing Academy, AH Green Occupations Academy, AH Public Services Academy, MP Manufacturing Academy, MP Green Remodeling and Construction Academy, MP Animation Pathway, WCO Early Childhood Education Academy, WCO Green Career Academy, WCO Multimedia Academy, WCO Electronics Academy, PH CAD Pathway, PH Entrepreneurship Pathway, PH Carpentry Pathway, OG Travel and Tourism Academy, OG International Cuisine Pathway, SC Business Careers Pathway, SC Telecommunications Pathway, YB Automotive, YB Green Construction Academy, YB Pre-Engineering Pathway, IH Academy of Finance, IH Engineering Space Science Pathway, IH Carpentry, IH Teaching Academy, and the ST Multimedia Pathway.
		 
Program Support:
Perkins funds will be used to assist programs in the Arts, Media and Entertainment Industry Sector, the Building Trades and Construction Industry Sector, Education, Child Development and Family Services Industry, Energy and Utilities Industry Sector, Engineering and Design Industry Sector, Finance and Business Industry Sector, Health,Science and Medical Technology Industry Sector, Hospitality, Tourism and Recreation Industry Sector, Transportation Industry Sector and the Public Services Industry Sector.  Funds will also be used  to support Certificated FTE for courses that will be offered for the first time at Andrew Hill, WC Overfelt, Mt. Pleasant, Oak Grove and Independence.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006, Section 132
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Carl D. Perkins 132 Grant 2011-12 Grant Application for the East Side Union High School District.

Item:  13.02
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Extension of Measure G Program Management Agreement
	 
	 
	 
SGI has served as Bond Program Manager since the inception of the Measure E $298,000,000 Bond Program.  The Program Management Agreement was set to expire in December 2010 and Administration at that time requested, and the Board approved, a short contract extension.  The Measure G program funds are not yet fully expended and Program Management services are still needed in connection with that bond program.  Administration now recommends that the Measure G Program Management Agreement with SGI be extended to and including June 30, 2012.  
	 
The draft proposed amendment incorporates and reflects changes to contracting and reimbursement practices recommended by FCMAT in the January 2010 Extraordinary Audit and the County Office of Education and which have previously been approved by the Board.
	 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees extend the Measure G Program Management Agreement with SGI to and including June 30, 2012.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  14.06
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Approve Permanent Course Adoption for Aerospace Engineering, Digital Electronics, Elements of Human/Family Service, Genres of Composition, Introduction to Energy Management and Environmental Careers, Introduction to Engineering Design, Manufacturing I & II and Principles of Engineering
		 
		 
The Instructional Policies Committee (IPC) has reviewed Aerospace Engineering, Elements of Human/Family Service, Genres of Composition, Introduction to Energy Management and Environmental Careers, Introduction to Engineering Design, Manufacturing I & II and Principles of Engineering courses.  These courses was piloted during the 2010-2011 school year.  The course descriptions are included for your review.
		 
Aerospace Engineering
The major focus of this course is to expose students to the work of aeronautics, flight and engineering through the fields of aeronautics, aerospace engineering, and related areas of study.  Lessons engage students in engineering design problems related to aerospace information systems, astronautics, rocketry, propulsion, the physics of space science,  space life sciences, the biology of space science, principles of aeronautics, structures and materials, and systems engineering.  Students work in teams utilizing hands-on activities, projects, and problems and are exposed to various situations based by aerospace engineers.  In addition, students use 3D design software to help design solutions to proposed problems.  Students design intelligent vehicles to learn about documenting their project, solving problems, and communicating their solutions to their peers and members of the professional community.
		 
Digital Electronics
This course is the study of electronic circuits that are used to process and control digital signals.  Digital electronics is the foundation of all modern electronic devices such as cellular phones, MP3 players, laptop computers, digital cameras, and high-definition televisions. The major focus of the DE course is to expose students to the design process of combinational and sequential logic design, teamwork, communication methods, engineering standards and technical documentation.
		 
Elements of Human/Family Service
This course will assist the students in examining the components of career choice.  The focus in on career, personal and education awareness as they relate to the process of selecting a career and/or program of study at a university.  Students will identify personal interests, values, abilities and skills and will use self-assessment instruments to help them identify career options and goals.  Lifestyles and personal satisfaction will be discussed as related to the world of work.  Decision making strategies, resume writing, interviewing skills and job search techniques will be reviewed.  Students in the course will learn to assess their strengths and weaknesses and potential for personal growth.  Students will take the ADVAB career aptitude test.  In addition, students will examine the community service issues that are experienced by clients and providers of family service agencies, including drug/alcohol abuse, domestic violence, health issues, disabilities and mental illness.
		 
Genres of Composition
This is a two-semester English credit course that offers additional preparation in composition and response techniques, exploring a broad range of rhetorical modes (narrative, argumentation, informational expository, analytical expository, business communication, technical writing) with an emphasis on understanding nonfiction text.  Students perform multiple pieces of writing, composing a minimum of six original multiple-paragraph essays aligned with the California Content Standards for English/Language Arts Standards.  Class can not be repeated.
		 
Introduction to Energy Management and Environmental Careers
This course gives an overview of the field of Energy Management and its importance in today's society, including future implications, and discussion of careers and impact on modern culture and society.  This module introduces the whole building concept and related energy and conservation issues including the building envelope, HVAC systems, lighting, energy management and controls renewable energy technologies.
		 
Introduction to Engineering Design
In this course, students use 3D solid modeling design software to help them design solutions to solve proposed problems.  Students will learn how to document their work and communicate solutions to peers and members of the professional community.  The major focus of the IED course is to expose students to the design process, research and analysis, teamwork, communication methods, global and human impacts, engineering standards and technical documentation.
		 
Manufacturing I
The Manufacturing I course will teach students the foundational manufacturing processes which are essential to the manufacturing industry.  In this hands-on course, students will learn the safe operation of the drill press, metal lathe, milling machine, sheet metal equipment and arc welding.  Students also learn to thread using taps and dies, and strengthen their basic measuring and precision measuring skills.  Students will make a variety of projects using all of the machines mentioned above as well as various sanders and grinders.
		 
Manufacturing II
The Manufacturing II course will introduce students to AutoCAD, SolidWorks, CNC programing and operating various CNC machinery.  AutoCAD is a two dimensional design software package while SolidWorks is a 3-dimensional solid modeling design package.  The students will study AutoCAD and SolidWorks for the first semester, then study CNC programming and the operation of CNC machinery the second semester.  CNC programming involves using the Cartesian Coordinate System to describe geometry.  The computer code is written so that the CNC machine will operate automatically to cut geometry described by the program.  The programming is written in two formats: conversational and G & M codes.  Students will operate CNC machinery in order to complete various hands-on projects.
		 
Principles of Engineering
This survey course of engineering exposes students to some of the major concepts they will encounter in a postsecondary engineering course of study.  Students have an opportunity to investigate engineering and high-tech careers and to develop skills and understanding of course concepts.  Students employ engineering and scientific concepts in the solution of engineering design problems.  They develop problem-solving skills and apply their knowledge of research and design to create solutions to various challenges.  Students also learn how to document their work and communicate their solutions to peers and members of the professional community.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the above courses.
